citations.narrative:
In the last month the facility has lost two golden pheasants to what the facility believes are owl attacks. The most recent
attack happened the night before the inspection and the predated body of the pheasant was caught between the perch
and the outer netting on the enclosure. The head and a large section of the chest cavity were missing. Both of the
predated pheasants were held in the enclosure listed as number 12 on the facility's inventory. Predation has caused the
death of two birds at the facility and could cause future deaths or injuries.
All housing facilities for birds must be designed and constructed so that they are structurally sound for the species of bird
housed in them. They must be kept in good repair, protect the birds from injury, and restrict other animals from entering
that may negatively affect the welfare of the birds within.
Correction date: January 14th, 2025

The facility did not have a complete record demonstrating the type and number of animals and birds on hand. There were
more ducks, peacocks, reeves pheasants, fallow dear and Guineafowl present then were listed on the provided inventory.
There were 28 domestic goats listed on the inventory and only 16 were present at the time of inspection. Neither golden
pheasant death had been recorded and only one of which had occurred the night before inspection. There were two fallow
deer fawns listed with no date of birth.
An accurate animal inventory is required so that USDA inspectors can ensure all animals are accounted for and receiving
adequate veterinary care.
Records of animal acquisition and disposition, including births/hatchings and deaths, must be kept by the facility to ensure
animals can be traced in case of an animal disease outbreak and to ensure there are not high mortality rates in the
animals. An accurate inventory and records of animal acquisition and disposition, including source of the animal,
births/hatchings and deaths, must be maintained by the facility. All records should be maintained for 1 year following the
disposition of the animal.

There were no available pools or aquatic areas in two duck enclosures or for the free ranging ducks. There was one
enclosure that had a stock water trough in it that was empty and turned over to avoid freezing. Two of the enclosures had
more than ten ducks in them.
The aquatic areas in the enclosures housing aquatic birds are either absent, not filled, and/or not large enough to allow
the birds to make normal postural and social adjustments. This deficiency can lead to malnutrition, poor condition, debility,
stress, and/or abnormal behavioral patterns.
Primary enclosures housing wading and aquatic birds must contain a pool or other aquatic area and a dry area that allows
easy ingress or egress of the pool or other aquatic area. Pools and other aquatic areas must be of sufficient surface area
and depth to allow each bird to make normal postural and social adjustments, such as immersion, bathing, swimming, and
foraging, with adequate freedom of movement and freedom to escape from aggression demonstrated by other birds in the
enclosure.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
Additional Inspectors:
Kristin Ray, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
3.150(a)  Critical
   
Facilities, general. 
In the last month the facility has lost two golden pheasants to what the facility believes are owl attacks. The most recent 
attack happened the night before the inspection and the predated body of the pheasant was caught between the perch 
and the outer netting on the enclosure. The head and a large section of the chest cavity were missing. Both of the 
predated pheasants were held in the enclosure listed as number 12 on the facility's inventory. Predation has caused the 
death of two birds at the facility and could cause future deaths or injuries.  
All housing facilities for birds must be designed and constructed so that they are structurally sound for the species of bird 
housed in them. They must be kept in good repair, protect the birds from injury, and restrict other animals from entering 
that may negatively affect the welfare of the birds within. 
Correction date: January 14th, 2025 
2.75(b)(1)  Repeat
   
Records: Dealers and exhibitors. 
The facility did not have a complete record demonstrating the type and number of animals and birds on hand. There were 
more ducks, peacocks, reeves pheasants, fallow dear and Guineafowl present then were listed on the provided inventory. 
There were 28 domestic goats listed on the inventory and only 16 were present at the time of inspection. Neither golden 
pheasant death had been recorded and only one of which had occurred the night before inspection. There were two fallow 
deer fawns listed with no date of birth.  
An accurate animal inventory is required so that USDA inspectors can ensure all animals are accounted for and receiving 
adequate veterinary care. 
Records of animal acquisition and disposition, including births/hatchings and deaths, must be kept by the facility to ensure 
animals can be traced in case of an animal disease outbreak and to ensure there are not high mortality rates in the 
animals. An accurate inventory and records of animal acquisition and disposition, including source of the animal, 
births/hatchings and deaths, must be maintained by the facility. All records should be maintained for 1 year following the 
disposition of the animal. 
3.153(c)  Repeat
   
Primary enclosures.

There were no available pools or aquatic areas in two duck enclosures or for the free ranging ducks. There was one 
enclosure that had a stock water trough in it that was empty and turned over to avoid freezing. Two of the enclosures had 
more than ten ducks in them.  
The aquatic areas in the enclosures housing aquatic birds are either absent, not filled, and/or not large enough to allow 
the birds to make normal postural and social adjustments. This deficiency can lead to malnutrition, poor condition, debility, 
stress, and/or abnormal behavioral patterns. 
Primary enclosures housing wading and aquatic birds must contain a pool or other aquatic area and a dry area that allows 
easy ingress or egress of the pool or other aquatic area. Pools and other aquatic areas must be of sufficient surface area 
and depth to allow each bird to make normal postural and social adjustments, such as immersion, bathing, swimming, and 
foraging, with adequate freedom of movement and freedom to escape from aggression demonstrated by other birds in the 
enclosure. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
Kristin Ray, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
